title: Ikan Bakar
description: Grilled fish marinated with spices, usually wrapped in banana leaf and served with sambal.
instructions: Clean the fish and make slits on both sides.
Marinate fish with chili paste, turmeric, tamarind juice, and salt.
Wrap fish in banana leaf.
Grill over charcoal until cooked and slightly charred.
Serve hot with sambal and rice.

title: Char Kway Teow
description: Penang signature stir-fried noodles with prawns, eggs, and bean sprouts.
instructions: Heat wok, fry prawns.
Add noodles and egg.
Mix in bean sprouts and chili paste.
Serve hot.

title: Nasi Kandar
description: Steamed rice served with a variety of curries and fried chicken.
instructions: Cook rice until fluffy.
Prepare assorted curries.
Fry chicken until crispy.
Serve rice with curries and sides.

title: Pekasam Puyu
description: A traditional Malay fermented dish made with freshwater fish (puyu), rice, and salt, giving a unique sour and savory flavor.
instructions: Clean the fish thoroughly and drain excess water.
Rub the fish with salt and sugar, then coat with ground roasted rice.
Layer the fish in a container and add bird’s eye chilies if desired.
Seal the container and leave to ferment for 1–2 weeks.
When ready, deep fry the fish until golden and crispy.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

title: Loh Bak
description: A popular Chinese dish of marinated minced pork wrapped in bean curd skin and deep fried.
instructions: In a bowl, mix minced pork with five-spice powder, soy sauce, oyster sauce, egg, and cornflour.
Lay bean curd skin flat and cut into rectangular sheets.
Spoon pork mixture onto bean curd skin and roll into logs.
Seal the edges with a bit of water or egg wash.
Heat oil and deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
Slice and serve with chili sauce or sweet sauce.

title: Apam Perlis
description: A soft and fluffy traditional steamed rice cake, sweet and slightly sour from natural fermentation, popular in Perlis as a street snack or dessert.
instructions: Mix rice flour, sugar, yeast, and coconut milk into a smooth batter.
Cover and let the batter ferment for 4–6 hours until bubbly.
Prepare steamer and line with banana leaves if using.
Pour batter into small cups or moulds.
Steam for 15–20 minutes until cooked and fluffy.
Serve warm, plain or with grated coconut.

title: Nasi Lemuni
description: A herbal rice dish cooked with daun lemuni, giving it a unique aroma and slightly bitter taste, often enjoyed as a Malay breakfast in Perak.
instructions: Wash and prepare daun lemuni leaves.
Cook rice with coconut milk, lemongrass, and daun lemuni.
Add salt to taste.
Serve hot with sambal, fried chicken, or anchovies.

title: Ipoh Bean Sprout Chicken
description: A famous Chinese dish from Ipoh, consisting of poached chicken served with crunchy bean sprouts and soy sauce.
instructions: Poach chicken until tender, then cut into pieces.
Blanch bean sprouts briefly in hot water.
Arrange chicken and bean sprouts on a plate.
Drizzle with soy sauce, sesame oil, and fried garlic.
Garnish with spring onions and serve with rice or noodles.

title: Appam Perak
description: A soft and fluffy South Indian-style fermented rice pancake, slightly sour and often paired with curry or coconut milk, popular in Perak.
instructions: Mix rice flour, sugar, yeast, and coconut milk into a smooth batter.
Allow to ferment for 3-4 hours.
Heat a small pan and pour in batter, swirling to coat the edges.
Cover and cook until soft in the middle and crispy on the sides.
Serve hot with curry or sweet coconut milk.

title: Satay Kajang
description: Grilled skewers of meat served with peanut sauce.
instructions: Marinate meat with spices.
Grill skewers until cooked.
Serve with peanut sauce and cucumber.

title: Bak Kut Teh
description: Pork rib herbal soup with garlic and herbs.
instructions: Simmer pork ribs with herbs for 2 hours.
Serve hot with rice and fried dough sticks.

title: Banana Leaf Rice
description: A traditional South Indian meal served on a banana leaf, featuring steamed rice, assorted curries, vegetables, pickles, and fried snacks.
instructions: Steam the rice until fluffy.
Prepare assorted curries, sambar, vegetables, and fried snacks.
Wash and pat dry a banana leaf.
Serve a portion of rice in the center of the banana leaf.
Arrange curries, vegetables, fried snacks, and pickles around the rice.
Eat with hands, mixing curries and rice as desired.

title: Nyonya Laksa
description: A spicy and tangy coconut-based noodle soup with prawns and tofu puffs, typical of Malacca's Nyonya cuisine.
instructions: Prepare laksa paste and coconut milk base.
Cook prawns and tofu puffs in the soup.
Boil rice noodles separately.
Assemble noodles in a bowl, pour laksa soup on top.
Garnish with bean sprouts and mint leaves.
Serve hot.

title: Chicken Rice Ball
description: A traditional Malacca Chinese dish with steamed chicken and rice shaped into balls.
instructions: Cook rice with chicken broth until fluffy.
Poach or steam the chicken until tender.
Shape rice into small balls.
Serve chicken pieces with rice balls and drizzle with soy sauce.
Garnish with ginger and spring onions.

title: Putu Piring
description: Steamed rice flour cakes filled with palm sugar and topped with grated coconut, a popular Indian/Malay dessert in Malacca.
ingredients: Banana leaf or small molds for steaming
instructions: Prepare rice flour mixture and form small cups.
Fill with palm sugar and top with grated coconut.
Steam for 10–15 minutes until cooked.
Serve warm as dessert or snack.

title: Masak Lemak Cili Padi
description: A traditional Malay dish from Negeri Sembilan made with chili padi and coconut milk, often cooked with fish or chicken, known for its rich and spicy flavor.
instructions: Pound or blend chilies with lemongrass and other spices to make a paste.
Sauté the paste until fragrant.
Add chicken or fish and stir to coat with paste.
Pour in coconut milk and add kaffir lime leaves.
Simmer until cooked and flavors are absorbed.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

title: Seremban-style Baked Crab
description: A famous Chinese seafood dish from Seremban, Negeri Sembilan, featuring fresh crab baked with a savory and slightly sweet sauce.
instructions: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F).
Clean crabs and crack claws slightly for flavor absorption.
Mix oyster sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and minced garlic to make the sauce.
Brush crabs with a little oil and place on a baking tray.
Pour the sauce over the crabs, ensuring even coating.
Bake for 20–25 minutes until crabs are cooked and sauce thickened.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

title: Vadai
description: A traditional South Indian deep-fried snack made from lentil batter, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, popular in Malaysia.
ingredients: 1 cup urad dal (split black gram lentils), soaked 4 hours
instructions: Drain soaked lentils and grind into a smooth batter.
Mix in onion, green chilies, cumin seeds, curry leaves, and salt.
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Shape batter into small patties or doughnut shapes.
Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
Drain excess oil and serve hot with chutney or curry.

title: Otak-Otak
description: A traditional Malay snack from Johor made of spiced fish paste wrapped in banana leaves and grilled or steamed.
instructions: Mix fish paste with coconut milk, chili paste, turmeric, salt, and sugar.
Cut banana leaves into rectangles and soften over heat.
Place a portion of fish paste on banana leaf and wrap tightly.
Grill over medium heat or steam until cooked.
Serve hot as snack or side dish.

title: Laksa Johor
description: A unique Johor-style laksa using spaghetti instead of rice noodles, served with a rich fish-based gravy and local herbs.
instructions: Cook spaghetti until al dente and set aside.
Prepare fish-based gravy using laksa paste and coconut milk.
Add cooked fish to the gravy and simmer briefly.
Assemble spaghetti in a bowl, pour gravy on top.
Garnish with bean sprouts and fresh herbs.
Serve immediately.

title: Kothu Parotta
description: A flavorful South Indian dish made by chopping parotta and stir-frying with eggs, meat, and spices.
ingredients: 1 tsp curry powder or garam masala
instructions: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions, garlic, ginger, and green chilies until fragrant.
Add chopped meat and tomato, cook until heated through.
Push the mixture to one side and scramble the egg on the other side.
Mix in shredded parotta and curry powder, stir-fry everything together.
Cook for 3-5 minutes until well combined and slightly crispy.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot.

title: Gulai Ikan Temenung
description: A traditional Malay fish curry from Kedah made with Temenung fish, coconut milk, and spices, known for its rich and aromatic flavor.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add curry powder, lemongrass, and chilies, stir well.
Add fish and coat with spice mixture.
Pour in coconut milk and simmer until fish is cooked and sauce thickens.
Season with salt and sugar.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

title: Curry Mee
description: A spicy and flavorful Chinese noodle soup from Malaysia, made with coconut curry broth, noodles, tofu, bean sprouts, and sometimes seafood or chicken.
instructions: Cook noodles according to package instructions and drain.
In a pot, sauté garlic and curry paste until fragrant.
Add coconut milk and chili paste, bring to a simmer.
Add tofu, bean sprouts, and optional chicken or prawns, cook until heated through.
Season with salt.
Serve noodles in a bowl and pour curry soup over. Garnish with herbs if desired.

title: Roti Canai Tsunami
description: A creative variation of the traditional Indian Muslim Roti Canai, known for its layered, fluffy texture and served with curry, popular in Kedah and northern Malaysia.
instructions: Mix flour, water, egg, ghee, and salt to form a smooth dough.
Knead well and let it rest for 1–2 hours.
Divide dough into small balls and roll into thin sheets.
Fold and roll sheets to create layered texture (like waves).
Pan-fry on medium heat with oil until golden and fluffy.
Serve hot with dhal curry or chicken curry.

title: Nasi Kerabu
description: Blue rice with herbs, fried chicken, and salted egg.
instructions: Cook rice with blue pea flower.
Fry chicken until crispy.
Serve with herbs and salted egg.

title: Prawn Mee
description: A flavorful Chinese noodle soup made with prawns, pork, and a rich shrimp-based broth, popular in Kelantan and other parts of Malaysia.
instructions: Boil shrimp shells in water to make a rich broth.
Sauté garlic and add prawns and pork slices, cook briefly.
Strain broth and return to pot, season with salt and pepper.
Cook noodles separately.
Assemble noodles in a bowl, pour hot prawn broth over, top with prawns, pork, bean sprouts, and spring onions.
Serve immediately.

title: Roti Jala
description: A traditional lacy Malaysian pancake popular in Kelantan, usually served with chicken or beef curry.
instructions: Mix flour, eggs, coconut milk, turmeric, and salt to form a smooth batter.
Pour batter through a roti jala mold onto a heated non-stick pan to form lacy pancakes.
Cook until lightly golden on both sides.
Serve with chicken or beef curry.

title: Nasi Dagang Terengganu
description: A traditional Terengganu Malay dish consisting of steamed coconut rice served with fish curry and pickled vegetables, popular for breakfast.
instructions: Soak glutinous rice for several hours, then steam until partially cooked.
Mix in coconut milk and continue steaming until fully cooked.
Prepare fish curry by cooking fish with curry paste and seasonings.
Serve coconut rice with fish curry on the side and pickled vegetables.
Enjoy hot, typically for breakfast.

title: Teochew Porridge
description: A light and comforting Chinese-style rice porridge popular in Terengganu, served with assorted side dishes like salted egg, pickled vegetables, and fried tofu.
ingredients: Assorted side dishes: salted egg, pickled vegetables, fried tofu, fish or chicken
instructions: Rinse rice and add to a pot with water or chicken broth.
Bring to a boil, then simmer on low heat for 45–60 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Add salt to taste.
Serve porridge hot with assorted side dishes.

title: Thosai
description: A traditional South Indian thin pancake made from fermented rice and lentil batter, commonly served with curry or chutney, popular in Terengganu Indian Muslim stalls.
instructions: Soak rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 4–6 hours.
Grind into a smooth batter and mix together, then let ferment overnight.
Heat a non-stick pan and spread a ladleful of batter thinly to form a pancake.
Drizzle a little oil around the edges and cook until golden and crispy.
Serve hot with sambar, coconut chutney, or curry.

title: Ikan Patin Masak Tempoyak
description: A traditional Pahang Malay dish featuring Patin fish cooked in a fermented durian (tempoyak) curry, known for its unique sour and spicy flavor.
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and chilies until fragrant.
Add tempoyak and tamarind juice, stir well.
Add Patin fish and pour in coconut milk.
Simmer until fish is cooked and sauce thickens.
Season with salt and sugar.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

title: Durian Cendol
description: A popular Malaysian dessert from Pahang featuring green rice flour jelly (cendol), coconut milk, palm sugar syrup, and fresh durian flesh.
instructions: Prepare cendol by boiling green rice flour jelly or buy pre-made.
In a bowl, add cendol and crushed ice.
Pour coconut milk and palm sugar syrup over.
Top with fresh durian flesh.
Serve immediately.

title: Murtabak
description: Stuffed flatbread with minced meat and egg, pan-fried.
instructions: Prepare dough and filling.
Stuff, fold, and fry.
Serve with curry.

title: Midin Goreng
description: A popular Sarawak Malay vegetable dish made from midin (wild jungle fern), stir-fried with garlic and shrimp paste, commonly served as a side dish.
instructions: Heat oil in a wok and sauté garlic and chilies until fragrant.
Add shrimp paste and stir-fry briefly.
Add midin and stir-fry for 3–4 minutes until cooked but still crisp.
Season with salt if needed.
Serve hot as a side dish.

title: Kolo Mee
description: Dry tossed noodles with char siu and minced meat.
instructions: Boil noodles, toss with soy sauce.
Top with char siu and minced pork.
Serve hot.

title: Mee Mamak
description: Spicy Indian fried noodles with egg and tofu.
instructions: Heat wok and fry tofu and egg.
Add noodles and sauces.
Stir-fry until coated.
Serve with lime.

title: Hinava
description: A traditional Kadazan-Dusun dish from Sabah, featuring raw fish marinated in lime juice, mixed with shallots, chili, and local herbs.
ingredients: 200g fresh fish fillet (mackerel or tuna), sliced thinly
instructions: Place thinly sliced fish in a bowl and pour lime juice over it. Let it marinate for 15-20 minutes.
Add sliced onion, chilies, salt, and fresh herbs.
Toss gently to combine.
Serve chilled as an appetizer or side dish.

title: Tuaran Mee
description: A popular Chinese-style stir-fried noodle dish from Tuaran, Sabah, featuring springy noodles, egg, meat, and vegetables.
instructions: Cook noodles until al dente and drain.
Stir-fry garlic and meat until cooked.
Add vegetables and sauté briefly.
Add noodles and soy sauce, stir-fry until everything is well combined.
Push noodles aside, scramble egg, then mix together.
Serve hot.

title: Roti Canai with Curry
description: Classic Indian flatbread served with dhal curry.
instructions: Prepare dough and rest.
Stretch thin, fold, and pan-fry.
Serve with dhal curry.
